issue.title: [R] CentOS 7 not correctly identifying compiler version
issue.body:
***Note**: This issue was originally created as [ARROW-10856](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-10856). Please see the [migration documentation](https://gist.github.com/toddfarmer/12aa88361532d21902818a6044fda4c3) for further details.*

### Original Issue Description:
When I tried to use the example command like this in my R session:
```java

df <- read_parquet(system.file("v0.7.1.parquet", package="arrow"))
```
 

It shows error:
```java

> df <- read_parquet(system.file("v0.7.1.parquet", package="arrow"))
Error in io___MemoryMappedFile__Open(path, mode) :
 Cannot call io___MemoryMappedFile__Open(). Please use arrow::install_arrow() to install required runtime libraries.
```
I did try to install it with `arrow::install_arrow()` and it finishes successfully.

However, I still get the same error message mentioned above after that.

My session info is here:

 
```java

> sessioninfo::session_info()
─ Session info ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
 setting value
 version R version 4.0.2 (2020-06-22)
 os CentOS Linux 7 (Core)
 system x86_64, linux-gnu
 ui X11
 language (EN)
 collate en_US.UTF-8
 ctype en_US.UTF-8
 tz America/Detroit
 date 2020-12-08
─ Packages ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
 package * version date lib source
 arrow * 2.0.0 2020-10-20 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 assertthat 0.2.1 2019-03-21 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 bit 4.0.4 2020-08-04 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 bit64 4.0.5 2020-08-30 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 cli 2.2.0 2020-11-20 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 crayon 1.3.4 2017-09-16 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 fansi 0.4.1 2020-01-08 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 glue 1.4.2 2020-08-27 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 magrittr 2.0.1 2020-11-17 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 purrr 0.3.4 2020-04-17 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 R6 2.5.0 2020-10-28 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 rlang 0.4.9 2020-11-26 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 sessioninfo 1.1.1 2018-11-05 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 tidyselect 1.1.0 2020-05-11 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 vctrs 0.3.5 2020-11-17 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
 withr 2.3.0 2020-09-22 [1] CRAN (R 4.0.2)
[1] /home/yihsiao/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.0
[2] /sw/arcts/centos7/stacks/gcc/8.2.0/R/4.0.2/lib64/R/library
```
 

One thing I notice is that when installing the run time library, it doesn't get the correct compiler I have for C++ (8.2.0 rather than some version < 4.9)

 
```java

> arrow::install_arrow()
Installing package into '/home/yihsiao/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.0'
(as 'lib' is unspecified)
trying URL 'https://cloud.r-project.org/src/contrib/arrow_2.0.0.tar.gz'
Content type 'application/x-gzip' length 322592 bytes (315 KB)
==================================================
downloaded 315 KB
* installing *source* package 'arrow' ...
** package 'arrow' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked
** using staged installation
*** No C++ binaries found for centos-7
*** Successfully retrieved C++ source
*** Building C++ libraries
**** cmake
**** S3 support not available for gcc < 4.9; building with ARROW_S3=OFF
**** arrow
```

comments.body:
***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-10856?focusedCommentId=17246230) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
Since you're describing compiler mismatch, and the installation output suggests you're on CentOS 7, this sounds like ARROW-10780. The revised documentation as of that pull request is at https://ursalabs.org/arrow-r-nightly/articles/install.html#known-installation-issues. Does that help?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-10856?focusedCommentId=17246287) by Yi Hsiao (yihsiao):*
HI `[~npr]`, thanks for the timely response. However, it seems to me that it doesn't resolve the question.

My Linux distribution info:

 
```java

[yihsiao@gl-login1 ~]$ cat /etc/*-release

CentOS Linux release 7.8.2003 (Core)
```
 

I try to set `LIBARROW_BINARY` and `ARROW_R_DEV` as true and here are the logs I get:

 
```java

```
which confuses me because the path to the compiler seems to be right.
```java

[yihsiao@gl-login1 ~]$ which g++
/sw/arcts/centos7/gcc/8.2.0/bin/g++
[yihsiao@gl-login1 ~]$ which gcc
/sw/arcts/centos7/gcc/8.2.0/bin/gcc
```
However, based on the log message, it still gets a gcc compiler lower than 4.9 version.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-10856?focusedCommentId=17246637) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
Hmm. So we build with the same compiler settings that R has set in its Makeconf: https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tools/linuxlibs.R#L307-L311

What does `$(R CMD config CXX11) --version` return?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-10856?focusedCommentId=17246703) by Yi Hsiao (yihsiao):*
`[~npr]`  Good point. It says 8.2.0, though.
```java

[yihsiao@gl-login2 ~]$ $(R CMD config CXX11) --version
g++ (GCC) 8.2.0
Copyright (C) 2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions. There is NO
warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
```

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-10856?focusedCommentId=17246721) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
Interesting. Let's step back for a minute. You reported that the C++ build failed (that's why you got the message to install_arrow), but the message about gcc < 4.9 doesn't explain the build failure--it builds fine on gcc 4.8, just not with S3 support. Can you share the rest of the build output from where you built with `ARROW_R_DEV=true` so we can what happened? The compiler version selection is probably related but I can't tell how just yet.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-10856?focusedCommentId=17249988) by Jonathan Keane (jonkeane):*
Digging a little bit more, it looks like what was happening is that the environment variables `CC` and `CXX` weren't being picked up in the calls to cmake we used to identify what versions were available. On CentOS this resulted in the default versions of gcc being used even though newer versions were on the path and being used elsewhere. https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8932 adjusts the detection slightly to prevent this from happening.
